were delayed I was miserable & overcome
by a thousand fears; & when they arrived
and I saw the superscription of Elizabeth
or my father I hardly dared to read & ascer
tain my fate. Sometimes I thought that the
fiend followed me & might remind me
myby murdering my companion; withWhen these
thoughts ‸ I would not quit Henry for a
moment but followed him as his shadow
to protect him from his‸the fancied rage
of his destroyer. I felt as if I had commit
ted some great crime the conscious
ness of which haunted me. I was guiltless
but I had ‸indeed drawn down a horrible curse

to shake off.
I visited Edinburgh with languid
eyes & mind & yet that city might have
interrested the most unfortunate being.
Claierval did not like it so well as
Oxford for the antiquity of thate latter city was
pleasing to him. But the beauty & regu
larity of the new town ‸of Edinburgh delighted him; its
environs are also the most beautiful
in the world; Arthur's seat, St Bernards
Well & the Pentland hills– But I was im
patient to arrive at the termination
of my journey. and We left Edinburgh in
a week passing through Cooper, St Andrews
& Along the the banks of the Tay to Perth
Where our friend expected us; But I was
not in the mood to laugh & talk with
Strangers or enter into their feelings or plans
